trans-unit.source: How to: Configure a Service Bus Client Using Code
trans-unit.target: How to: Configure a Service Bus Client Using Code

trans-unit.source: How to: Configure a Service Bus Client Using Code
trans-unit.target: How to: Configure a Service Bus Client Using Code

trans-unit.source: Once you have defined the <token>sb2</token> interface in your code (as described in <link xlink:href="dfaace1b-c418-4e06-83cf-0261144ebd7a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Designing an AppFabric Service Bus Contract</link>), you can continue configuring the client application.
trans-unit.target: Once you have defined the <token>sb2</token> interface in your code (as described in <link xlink:href="dfaace1b-c418-4e06-83cf-0261144ebd7a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Designing an AppFabric Service Bus Contract</link>), you can continue configuring the client application.

trans-unit.source: Configuring a <token>sb2</token> client application programmatically is very similar to configuring any other <token>indigo1</token> application, which is described in detail in the <link xlink:href="beac771e-f28e-4f84-9ff1-ad9251c726d3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Configuring Services</link> topic in the <token>indigo2</token> documentation.
trans-unit.target: Configuring a <token>sb2</token> client application programmatically is very similar to configuring any other <token>indigo1</token> application, which is described in detail in the <link xlink:href="beac771e-f28e-4f84-9ff1-ad9251c726d3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Configuring Services</link> topic in the <token>indigo2</token> documentation.

trans-unit.source: The following topic describes how to programmatically create and configure a simple client that uses the <codeEntityReference qualifyHint="false">T:Microsoft.ServiceBus.NetTcpRelayBinding</codeEntityReference> binding, and also a discussion of issues specific to <token>sb2</token>.
trans-unit.target: The following topic describes how to programmatically create and configure a simple client that uses the <codeEntityReference qualifyHint="false">T:Microsoft.ServiceBus.NetTcpRelayBinding</codeEntityReference> binding, and also a discussion of issues specific to <token>sb2</token>.

trans-unit.source: The main difference between configuring a service and a client is that clients must know some of the configuration settings that are used by the service, and comply with them.
trans-unit.target: The main difference between configuring a service and a client is that clients must know some of the configuration settings that are used by the service, and comply with them.

trans-unit.source: These settings include the type of binding to use, and also what security options you must have to access the service (that is, authentication and transport-level security.)
trans-unit.target: These settings include the type of binding to use, and also what security options you must have to access the service (that is, authentication and transport-level security.)

trans-unit.source: <token>crabout</token> setting security, see <link xlink:href="defd9147-3244-49e5-8304-09dc8ad9bac5" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Securing and Authenticating an AppFabric Service Bus Connection</link>.
trans-unit.target: <token>crabout</token> setting security, see <link xlink:href="defd9147-3244-49e5-8304-09dc8ad9bac5" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Securing and Authenticating an AppFabric Service Bus Connection</link>.

trans-unit.source: To configure a Service Bus client using code
trans-unit.target: To configure a Service Bus client using code

trans-unit.source: Define the endpoint using the namespace name and schema type.
trans-unit.target: Define the endpoint using the namespace name and schema type.

trans-unit.source: In this context, the schema type is “sb”, indicating <token>sb2</token>, and the namespace is “ServiceBusTutorial”.
trans-unit.target: In this context, the schema type is “sb”, indicating <token>sb2</token>, and the namespace is “ServiceBusTutorial”.

trans-unit.source: In your code, substitute “YOUR ISSUER NAME” and “YOUR ISSUER SECRET” with the issuer name and secret you want to use when you connect to the service endpoint.
trans-unit.target: In your code, substitute “YOUR ISSUER NAME” and “YOUR ISSUER SECRET” with the issuer name and secret you want to use when you connect to the service endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Create and initialize the channel factory with the endpoint, binding type, and contract type:
trans-unit.target: Create and initialize the channel factory with the endpoint, binding type, and contract type:

trans-unit.source: You have now configured the client application.
trans-unit.target: You have now configured the client application.

trans-unit.source: You can move on to implementing the rest of the client application, in <link xlink:href="3468b3db-91b6-4e76-a5ff-216d4c765d05" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Building an AppFabric Service Bus Client Application</link>.
trans-unit.target: You can move on to implementing the rest of the client application, in <link xlink:href="3468b3db-91b6-4e76-a5ff-216d4c765d05" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Building an AppFabric Service Bus Client Application</link>.

trans-unit.source: Note that this tutorial does use an App.config file; however, it is used only to store name and password information in a string, and is easily replaced by the code used in this procedure.
trans-unit.target: Note that this tutorial does use an App.config file; however, it is used only to store name and password information in a string, and is easily replaced by the code used in this procedure.
